Name: A/B Testing
Definition: Testing "that allows testers to determine which of two systems or components performs better" (IEEE, 2022, p.1)
Synonym(s): Split-Run Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp.1, 35)
Notes: "Not a test case generation technique as test inputs are not generated"; "us[es] the existing system as a partial oracle" (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)

Name: Acceptance Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted to enable a user, customer, or other authorized entity to determine whether to accept a system or component" and whether it "satisfies its acceptance criteria" (IEEE, 2017, p. 5)
Notes: "May or may not involve the developers of the system" (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-6). Related to usability testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439) and validation tests (IEEE, 2017, p. 5)

Name: Acceptance Tests
Definition: Tests "of a system or functional unit usually performed by the purchaser … with the … vendor to ensure that the contractual requirements are met" (IEEE, 2017, p. 5)
Synonym(s): Qualification Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-6)
Notes: Difference between this and acceptance testing? Related to validation tests (IEEE, 2017, p. 5)

Name: Accessibility Testing
Definition: Testing "used to measure the degree to which a test item can be operated by users with the widest possible range of characteristics and abilities" (IEEE, 2022, p. 1; 2013, p. 2)
Parent(s): Usability Testing (IEEE, 2022, p.1) (although listed separately on p. 22)
Notes: Good to use when the software will be widely available or when it will be used by people with disabilities (IEEE, 2022, p. 45)

Name: Ad Hoc Testing
Definition: Testing where "test cases are derived by relying on the software engineer’s skill, intuition, and experience with similar programs" to "identify[] test cases that are not easily generated by more formalized techniques" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)

Name: Adaptive Random Testing
Definition: Random testing "in which other input selection criteria direct the random input sampling" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Notes: Kind of a vague definition; what are these criteria?

Name: All Combinations Testing
Definition: Testing that "focuses on all … the possible input combinations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)

Name: All-C-Uses Testing
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: See also IEEE (2017, p. 115) and van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-Definitions Testing
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: A "weaker strateg[y]" than all-DU-paths testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-DU-Paths Testing
Definition: Testing that "requires executing, for each variable, every control flow path segment from a definition of that variable to the use of that definition" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: "The strongest data flow testing criterion" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). See also IEEE (2017, pp. 115, 125) and van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-P-Uses Testing
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: See also IEEE (2017, p. 115) and van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: All-Uses Testing
Parent(s): Data Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: A "weaker strateg[y]" than all-DU-paths testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: Alpha Testing
Definition: The "first stage of testing before a product is considered ready for commercial or operational use" (IEEE, 2017, p. 17)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22); Unscripted Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: "Often performed only by users within the organization developing the software" (IEEE, 2017, p. 17) or "a small, selected group of potential users" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8). Related to beta testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 17; Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)

Name: API Testing
Definition: A specific form of interface testing that "simulate[s] the use of APIs by end-user applications", including "generating parameters" and "defining internal data" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Synonym(s): Application Program Interface Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)

Name: Attacks
Definition: Testing with the goal of "exploiting a specific … way of thinking about how and why software fails … [which] can be behaviour-based" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)
Notes: "An example of a security attack would be to block access to software libraries" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34). This term can also be defined as a "malicious action or interaction with the system or its environment that has the potential to result in a fault or an error, and thereby possibly in a failure, or an adverse consequence" (IEEE, 2019, p. 7) which is essentially the same definition with the modification of being "malicious"; like the difference between white- and black-hat hacking

Name: Audits
Definition: "Independent examination[s] of … work products to assess compliance with specifications, standards, contractual agreements, or other criteria" (IEEE, 2017, p. 36)
Notes: Also described as testing "used to verify compliance with standards" (IEEE, 2022, p. 44). See also ISO 24765; couldn't find original source: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016

Name: Automated Testing
Definition: Testing "executed by a test automation tool" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35)
Notes: Often cost-effective "if a set of test cases is going to be executed 5 or more times" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35). See also "automated verification system " (IEEE, 2017, p. 37)

Name: Back-to-Back Testing
Definition: Testing "whereby an alternative version of the system is used to generate expected results for comparison from the same test inputs" (IEEE, 2022, p.2) or where "two or more variants of a program are executed with the same inputs, the outputs are compared, and errors are analyzed in case of discrepancies" (IEEE, 2017, p. 38)
Synonym(s): Differential Testing (IEEE, 2022, p.2)
Notes: "Not a test case generation technique as test inputs are not generated" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35). Similar to testing using a pseudo-oracle (Barr et al., 2015, p. 515)

Name: Backup and Recovery Testing
Definition: Testing "that measures the degree to which system state can be restored from backup within specified parameters of time, cost, completeness, and accuracy in the event of failure" (IEEE, 2013, p. 2)
Notes: Nonatomic; captures both "backup" and "recovery". Seems to be what is meant by "recovery testing" in the context of performance

Name: Beta Testing
Definition: The "second stage of testing when a product is in limited production use" (IEEE, 2017, p. 17)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22); Unscripted Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: "Often performed at a customer site" (IEEE, 2017, p. 45) by "a larger set of representative users" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8); related to alpha testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)

Name: Big-Bang Testing
Definition: "Testing in which … [components of a system] are combined all at once into an overall system, rather than in stages" (IEEE, 2017, p. 45)

Name: Boundary Value Analysis
Definition: Testing "based on exercising the boundaries of equivalence partitions" (IEEE, 2022, p.2)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 22), Equivalence Partitioning (IEEE, 2022, p. 2), Functional Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 20)
Notes: Seems to be related to stress testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 49); See also Patton, 2006, pp. 70-74

Name: Branch Condition Combination Testing
Synonym(s): (Multiple) Condition Testing? (Patton, 2006, p. 120), Extended Branch Coverage? (van Vliet, 2000, p. 422)
Notes: Difference between this and branch condition testing?

Name: Branch Condition Testing
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Synonym(s): (Multiple) Condition Testing? (Patton, 2006, p. 120), Extended Branch Coverage? (van Vliet, 2000, p. 422)
Notes: Difference between this and branch condition combination testing?

Name: Branch Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising branches in the control flow of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 2)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 22)
Notes: IEEE (2017, p. 51) says it is "designed to execute each outcome of each decision point"; is this level of coverage required or advised?

Name: Buddy Testing
Definition: Testing that "generates test cases by using internal architecture knowledge and testing specific knowledge" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14); this definition seems vague
Notes: Related to pair testing?

Name: Business Process Testing
Definition: Scenario-based testing focused "on the roles in a workflow specification" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)

Name: Capacity Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted to evaluate the level at which increasing load (of users, transactions, data storage, etc.) compromises a test item’s ability to sustain required performance" (IEEE, 2013, p. 2)
Parent(s): Performance Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9); Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22); Performance Efficiency Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 58)
Notes: Could be subdivided into categories; from IEEE (2017): channel capacity (p. 67), memory capacity (p. 270), storage capacity (p. 441)

Name: Cause-Effect Graphing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules in a cause-effect graph" (IEEE, 2022, p. 2): a "logical network[] that map[s] a set of causes to a set of effects by systematically exploring the possible combinations of input conditions" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Notes: Related to decision table testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)

Name: Checklist-based Testing
Definition: Testing generated "based on a list of pre-determined items" that "can be based on personal experience, commonly found defects, and perceived risks" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)
Notes: "Often focused on a particular quality characteristic" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34). See also Patton, 2006, pp. 61, 99-103

Name: Code Review
Definition: A "meeting at which software code is presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, or other interested parties for comment or approval" (IEEE, 2017, p. 74)
Notes: Seems to line up most closely with the notion of "peer review" from Patton (2006, p. 94) and van Vliet (2000, p. 414)

Name: Co-existence Testing
Approach Category: Type (inferred from compatibility and interoperability testing)
Definition: "Testing that measures the degree to which a test item can function satisfactorily alongside other independent products in a shared environment" (IEEE, 2022, p. 3)
Notes: Not present in (IEEE, 2022); definition of "coexistence" also given in (International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022); see also ISO/IEC, 2023

Name: Combinatorial Testing
Definition: Testing that "systematically derive[s] … test cases that cover specific parameters of values or conditions" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Synonym(s): Combinatorial Test Design Techniques (IEEE, 2022, p. 3) (a little redundant)
Notes: See also Engström and Petersen, 2015

Name: Compatibility Testing
Definition: "Testing that measures the degree to which a test item can function satisfactorily alongside other independent products in a shared environment (co-existence), and where necessary, exchanges information with other systems or components (interoperability)" (IEEE, 2022, p. 3)
Notes: Not atomic; implies the existence of "co-existence testing" and "interoperability testing". Includes both "different hardware and software facilities" and "different versions or releases" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)

Name: Compliance Testing
Definition: Testing used "to demonstrate the SUT’s adherence to a law or regulation" usually "forced by an external regulatory body" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: "Audits are often used to verify compliance with standards" (IEEE, 2022, p. 44)

Name: Component Integration Testing
Approach Category: Level (inferred from component testing and integration testing)
Definition: "Testing of groups of related components" (IEEE, 2017, p. 82)
Notes: Difference between this, integration testing, and unit testing?

Name: Configuration Testing
Definition: Testing that "verifies the software under specified configurations" when it "is built to serve different users" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)

Name: Continuous Testing
Definition: Testing "started via an automated process that can occur on-demand" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35)
Notes: "Allow[s] early testing" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35) and should ideally imploy "prioritization", the process of "defin[ing] a test execution order according to some criteria" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-4), so that time isn't wasted on lower priority tests

Name: Control Flow Testing
Definition: Testing that "covers all" of a particular subdivision of code (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Notes: "The adequacy of such tests is measured in percentages" and can also be performed on "blocks of statements[] or specific combinations of statements" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13); would these be a different testing type?

Name: Data Flow Testing
Definition: Control flow testing with additional "information about how the variables are defined, used, and killed" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Control Flow Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Notes: See also IEEE (2017, p. 166), Patton (2006, p. 114) and van Vliet (2000, pp. 424-425)

Name: Decision Table Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision rules in a decision table" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4) "by considering every possible combination of conditions and their corresponding resultant actions" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22), Model-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10)
Notes: Decision Table: "tabular representation of decision rules between causes and effects" (IEEE, 2022, p.3). Related to cause-effect graphing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11). See also Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, pp. 448, 450-453

Name: Decision Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising decision outcomes in the control flow of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p.4)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22)
Synonym(s): Condition Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)

Name: Development Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted during the development of a system or component, usually in the development environment by the developer" (IEEE, 2017, p. 136)
Notes: The secondary definition, "testing conducted to establish whether a new software product or software‐based system (or components of it) satisfies its criteria" (IEEE, 2017, p. 136), seems to overlap with acceptance testing

Name: Disaster/Recovery Testing
Definition: Testing to determine the degree to which a system can "return to normal operation after a hardware or software failure " (IEEE, 2017, p. 140)
Notes: Difference between this and recovery testing (in the context of performance)?

Name: Dynamic Testing
Definition: "Testing in which a test item is evaluated by executing it" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4)
Notes: Can "only occur in the parts of the life cycle when executable code is available" (IEEE, 2022, p. 18)

Name: Elasticity Testing
Definition: Testing that "assesses the ability of the SUT … to rapidly expand or shrink compute, memory, and storage resources without compromising the capacity to meet peak utilization" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Notes: Some objectives are "to control behaviors, to identify the resources to be (un)allocated, to coordinate events in parallel, and to evaluate scalability" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9); the last one seems like it should be under scalability testing?

Name: Endurance Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted to evaluate whether a test item can sustain a required load continuously for a specified period of time" (IEEE, 2013, p. 2)

Name: Equivalence Partitioning
Definition: Testing "designed to exercise equivalence partitions by using one or more representative members of each partition" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; 2013, p. 3) "based on a specified criterion or relation" to create "a representative test suite" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Functional Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 20)
Synonym(s): Equivalence Classing (Patton, 2006, p. 67; implied in IEEE, 2022, p. 4)

Name: Error Guessing
Definition: Testing based on "the tester's knowledge of past failures, or general knowledge of failure modes" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4; 2013, p. 3) "to anticipate the most plausible faults in each SUT" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Experience-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22), Fault-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-9)
Notes: See also Patton, 2006, pp. 88-89

Name: Error Seeding
Definition: The "process of intentionally adding known faults to those already in a computer program … [to] monitor[] the rate of detection and removal, and estimating the number of faults remaining" (IEEE, 2017, p. 165)
Synonym(s): Fault Seeding (IEEE, 2017, p. 165; van Vliet, 2000, 427), Bug Seeding (IEEE, 2017, p. 165)
Notes: See also van Vliet (2000, pp. 427-428)

Name: Evidence-based Testing
Definition: Testing that "follows a rigorous research approach", including "identifying" and "critically analyzing the evidence in light of the problem" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Notes: "Evidence-based software engineering (EBSE) … is the _best_ solution for a practical problem" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12); related to experience-based testing?

Name: Exhaustive Testing
Definition: Testing "in which all combinations of input values and preconditions are tested" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4)
Notes: Impossible in most non-trivial situations (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-5; IEEE, 2022, p. 4; van Vliet, 2000, p. 421; Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, pp. 439, 461)

Name: Experience-based Testing
Approach Category: Technique (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, pp. 4, 22), Practice (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Definition: Testing "using the experience [and intuition (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)] of testers to generate test cases" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4), as well as the SUT's context (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 17), Unscripted Testing (often) (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)
Notes: "Can include concepts such as test attacks, tours, and error taxonomies" (IEEE, 2022, p. 4). See also Patton, 2006, pp. 88-89

Name: Exploratory Testing
Approach Category: Technique (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14; inferred from experience-based testing: IEEE, 2022, pp. 4-5), Practice (IEEE, 2022, pp. 20, 22, 34)
Definition: "Simultaneous learning, test design and test execution" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14) that aims to find "hidden properties" that "can interfere with other properties of the software under test" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5)
Parent(s): Experience-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14; IEEE, 2022, p. 5; 2013, p. 3); Unscripted Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 33; 2017, p. 174; implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Notes: "Test cases are not defined in advance but are dynamically designed, executed, and modified according to the collected evidence" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), but this process is often structured with "session sheets", which are also "used to capture information about what was tested, and any anomalous behaviour observed" (2022, p. 33). Patton says this is used when a specification is not available to determine and test the software's features (2006, p. 65). "Widely used in shift-left development (such as Agile)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14). See also Whittaker, 2010

Name: Failover Testing
Definition: Testing that "validates the SUT’s ability to manage heavy loads or unexpected failure to continue typical operations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Notes: Can be done by "allocating extra resources" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Related to recoverability validation (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)

Name: Fault Injection Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 42)
Notes: Can "test the robustness of the system in the event of internal and external failures" (IEEE, 2022, p. 42)

Name: Fault-Based Testing
Definition: Testing that "devise[s] test cases specifically to reveal likely or predefined fault categories" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)

Name: Forcing Exception Testing
Definition: Testing that "check[s] whether the SUT can manage a predefined set of exceptions/errors" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Notes: Related to the "test-to-fail" approach (Patton, 2006, pp. 66-67)

Name: Functional Suitability Testing
Definition: Testing to determine the "capability of a product to provide functions that meet stated and implied needs of intended users when it is used under specified conditions" (ISO/IEC, 2023)
Notes: This includes meeting "the functional specification" (ISO/IEC, 2023). Difference between this and functional testing?

Name: Functional Testing
Approach Category: Type (IEEE, 2022, pp. 15, 20, 22); "correctness" is a quality (IEEE, 2017, p. 104; Washizaki, 2024, p. 3-13) which is what defines a "test type" (IEEE, 2022, p. 15)
Definition: Testing "used to check the implementation of functional requirements" (IEEE, 2022, p. 21) and "to verify that the SUT conforms to standards, rules, specifications, requirements, design, processes, or practices" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)
Synonym(s): Conformance Testing, Correctness Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)

Name: Functional Testing
Definition: "Testing that … focuses solely on the outputs generated in response to selected inputs and execution conditions" or that "evaluate[s] the compliance of a system or component with specified functional requirements" (IEEE, 2017, p. 196) which "identif[y] what results" (IEEE, 2017, p. 195) or "observable behaviours that the software is to provide (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-4)
Synonym(s): Black-Box Testing (IEEE, 2017, p. 196; van Vliet, 2000, p. 399)
Notes: Difference between this and specification-based testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 399; Souza et al., 2017, p. 3)?

Name: Fuzz Testing
Approach Category: Technique? (IEEE, 2022, p. 36), Practice (inferred from mathematical-based testing), Approach (IEEE, 2022, p. 5)
Definition: Testing where "high volumes of random (or near random) data, called fuzz, are used to generate [test] inputs" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5) "aimed at breaking the software" (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8)
Parent(s): Mathematical-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 36), Random Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8; implied in IEEE, 2022, p. 5)
Notes: Often used for security testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8). This is tagged (?) as "artificial intelligence" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5), but I don't think AI is required

Name: Infrastructure Testing
Definition: Testing of "infrastructure components to reduce the chances of downtime and improve the performance of the IT infrastructure" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)

Name: Installability Testing
Notes: Related to portability testing? (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439)

Name: Installation Testing
Approach Category: Level (Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, p. 445; implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Definition: "System testing conducted in the operational environment of hardware configurations and other operational constraints"; may also verify installation procedures (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)

Name: Integration Testing
Definition: Testing that "verifies the interactions among SUT elements (for instance, components, modules, or subsystems)" as well as "external interfaces" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7).
Notes: Difference between this and component integration testing? "Can be performed at each development stage" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7). See also (Patton, 2006, p. 109)

Name: Interface Testing
Definition: Testing that "aims to verify whether the components' interface provides the correct exchange of data and control information" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Notes: "Usually, the test cases are generated from the interface specification" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10); related to integration testing?

Name: Interoperability Testing
Definition: "Testing that measures the degree to which a test item …, … where necessary, exchanges information with other systems or components" (IEEE, 2022, p. 3)
Notes: Not defined in (IEEE, 2022) but used on pages 22 and 43 (although the third usage seems like it should be "portabilty testing"); definition of "interoperability" also given in (International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022); see also ISO/IEC, 2023

Name: Keyword-driven Testing
Definition: "Testing using test cases composed from keywords": "one or more words used as a reference to a specific set of actions intended to be performed during" testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 5)
Notes: Keywords use at least one verb (IEEE, 2022, p. 5). See also ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-5

Name: Load Testing
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate the behaviour of a test item under anticipated conditions of varying load" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9); Performance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 5), Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: Loads used are "usually between anticipated conditions of low, typical, and peak usage" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5). Patton defines this as running the software with as large of a load as possible (2006, p. 86), and Washizaki (2024, p. 5-9) seems to imply something similar; going past this "limit" is the realm of "stress testing" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Seeks to "discover problems … or reliability, stability, or robustness violations" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Good to use if the software may have "a large number of concurrent users" (IEEE, 2022, p. 45)

Name: Maintainability Testing
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate the degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a test item may be modified" (IEEE, 2022, p. 5)

Name: Manual Testing
Definition: "Humans performing tests by entering information into a test item and verifying the results" (IEEE, 2022, p. 6)

Name: Mathematical-based Testing
Definition: Testing based on "the test item's required behaviour, input space or output space" when they "can be described in sufficient detail" (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)
Notes: Related to computation error testing from Patton (2006, p. 101)? See also ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4

Name: MC/DC Testing
Definition: Testing "based on demonstrating that a single Boolean condition within a decision can independently affect the outcome of the decision" (IEEE, 2022, p. 6)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 6, 22)
Synonym(s): Modified Condition Decision Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, p. 6)

Name: Metamorphic Testing
Definition: Testing "based on generating test cases based on existing test cases and metamorphic relations" (IEEE, 2022, p. 6)
Parent(s): Mutation Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15), Specification-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 6, 22)
Notes: Metamorphic Relation: "description of how changes to the test inputs for a test case affect the expected outputs" (IEEE, 2022, p. 6). Good to use when it is "difficult to calculate expected results" (IEEE, 2022, p. 45) See also Kanewala and Yueh Chen, 2019

Name: Model-based Testing
Definition: Testing that uses "formal or semi-formal representations of the required behaviour of a … [test] item" to "generate test cases systematically and automatically" at "various levels of abstraction" (IEEE, 2022, p. 32)
Synonym(s): MBT (IEEE, 2022, p. 32)
Notes: Models "vary in the degree of model formality" (such as Agile, semiformal, and formal models) (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-14). Good potential for automation/generation! See also Souza et al., 2017 (term used on p. 3) and Engström and Petersen, 2015

Name: Monkey Testing
Definition: Testing using "randomly generated test cases to cause the program to stop" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), Random Testing?, Fuzz Testing?
Notes: Related to fuzz testing?

Name: Mutation Testing
Definition: Testing where "test cases are randomly generated … or … specifically designed" to detect "slightly modified version[s] of the SUT" called "mutants" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)
Parent(s): Structure-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15), Fault-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-9)
Notes: Assumes that "that more complex but real faults will be found by looking for simple syntactic faults" and requires "many mutants … [to] be automatically generated and executed systematically"; can be used to generate fuzz testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)

Name: Negative Testing
Definition: "The application of boundary value concepts to scenario testing"? (IEEE, 2022, p. 40)
Parent(s): Security Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Forcing Exception Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Boundary Value Analysis?, Scenario-based Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 40)
Synonym(s): Invalid Testing, Dirty Testing (International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022)

Name: Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Definition: Testing that "targets the validation of non-functional aspects (such as performance, [security,] usability, or reliability)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8; IEEE, 2022, p. 21) that tend to "constrain the technologies to be used in the implementation" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-4)
Notes: Hundreds of subapproaches that can be "performed at all test leves" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8). In constrast to functional testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 21)

Name: Off-line Testing
Definition: Testing "in an environment without external interaction" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-6)

Name: Online Testing
Definition: Testing that "interacts with the real application environment" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-6)

Name: Operational (Acceptance) Testing
Definition: "Test[ing] to determine the correct installation, configuration and operation of a module and that it operates securely in the operational environment" (ISO/IEC, 2018) or "evaluate a system or component in its operational environment" (IEEE, 2017, p. 303), particularly "to determine if operations and/or systems administration staff can accept [it]" (International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022)
Parent(s): Acceptance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22; International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022; LambdaTest, 2024), Non-functional Testing (LambdaTest, 2024), Reliability Testing (likely incorrectly) (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-6)
Synonym(s): "Operational testing" and "operational acceptance testing" are treated as synonyms in this glossary

Name: Pair Testing
Definition: Testing involving "two individuals" where "one generates and runs the test cases[ and] the other observes and analyzes the testing process" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Notes: "Allows [for] generating test cases with broad and better test coverage" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14). Related to buddy testing?

Name: Pairwise Testing
Definition: Testing "in which test cases are designed to execute all possible discrete combinations of each pair of input parameters" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7)
Parent(s): Combinatorial Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22), Black-Box Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 7)
Synonym(s): Orthogonal Array Testing (OAT) (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11), although this seems disputed by other sources

Name: Path Testing
Definition: Testing that "aims to execute all entry-to-exit control flow paths in a SUT’s control flow graph" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Notes: "Exhaustive path testing is generally not feasible because of loops" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), and infeasible paths "are a significant problem" (p. 5-5)

Name: Performance Efficiency Testing
Notes: Difference between this and performance testing? Mentioned as the parent of stress testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)

Name: Performance Testing
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate the degree to which a test item accomplishes its designated functions within given constraints of time and other resources" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7) or within "specified performance requirements" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8); Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: Difference between this, performance efficiency testing, and performance-related testing? May be specific to "real-time constraints" (IEEE, 2022, p. 43)

Name: Performance-related Testing
Notes: Difference between this and performance testing?

Name: Portability Testing
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate the ease with which a test item can be transferred from one hardware or software environment to another, including the level of modification needed" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7)
Notes: Related to compatibility testing?

Name: Power Testing?
Definition: Testing "based on power consumption and battery failure" (IEEE, 2022, p. 43); term is original

Name: Prioritization Testing
Definition: Testing that "schedule[s] test cases to increase the rate [and likelihood] of fault detection, … the coverage of code under test, and … reliability" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: What does "schedule" mean in this context?

Name: Privacy Testing
Definition: Testing that "assess[es] the security and privacy of users’ personal data to prevent local attacks" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Notes: Assesses policies and profile/data management (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10); seems to overlap with IEEE's definition of security testing

Name: Procedure Testing
Definition: Testing "conducted to evaluate whether procedural instructions for interacting with a test item or using its outputs meet user requirements and support the purpose of their use" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7)

Name: Quick Testing
Definition: Testing "in which a very small test suite is selected and executed" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Notes: "Guarantees that no failure can be experienced because of SUT components that are not fully operational" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), but this is not elaborated on

Name: Random Testing
Approach Category: Technique (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22, 36), Practice? (inferred from mathematical-based testing)
Definition: Testing "based on generating test cases to exercise randomly selected test item inputs" (IEEE, 2022, p. 7)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; IEEE, 2022, pp. 7, 22), Usage-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15), Mathematical-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 36)
Notes: Often used in automated testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12) and reliability testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439). Implied to be related to statistical testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)

Name: Recovery Testing
Notes: Difference between this and disaster/recovery testing?

Name: Recovery Testing
Definition: Testing of "software restart capabilities after a system crash or other disasters [sic]" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Usability Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Notes: Difference between this and disaster/recovery testing?

Name: Regression Testing
Definition: "Testing performed following modifications to a test item or to its operational environment, to identify whether failures in unmodified parts of the test item occur" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8) and "to verify that modifications have not caused unintended effects" (IEEE, 2017, p. 372)
Parent(s): Functional Testing, Non-functional Testing, Continuous Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Synonym(s): Non-regression Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)
Notes: "Does not test that the modification works correctly"; this is "retesting" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8). Interesting to note it is sometimes described as such (IEEE, 2017, p. 372), maybe just in the sense of "testing again"? Should be part of any test strategy and its level should be "based on a knowledge of the risks associated with developers making changes" (IEEE, 2022, p. 23), although it can be applied to any level (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8).

Name: Reliability Testing
Definition: "Testing conducted to evaluate the ability of a test item to perform its required functions, including evaluating the frequency with which failures occur" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8)
Notes: The use of the test item is under "stated conditions for a specified period of time" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8). Often uses statistical models of user behaviour, reliability growth models (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), and/or random testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439) and facilitated by DevOps (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)

Name: Requirements-based Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising atomic requirements" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8)

Name: Response-Time Testing
Parent(s): Performance Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9); Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)
Notes: Good to use if the software may have "a large number of concurrent users" (IEEE, 2022, p. 45). See also ISO/IEC, 2023?

Name: Retesting
Definition: "Testing performed to check that modifications made to correct a fault have successfully removed the fault" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8)
Synonym(s): Confirmation Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 8)
Notes: Should be part of any test strategy and its level should be "based on a knowledge of the risks associated with developers making changes" (IEEE, 2022, p. 23). "In most cases, the original test cases associated with the fixed code are used for retesting, but they are sometimes supplemented by new test cases that provide improved coverage" (IEEE, 2022, p. 35)

Name: Reviews
Notes: See also ISO/IEC 20246

Name: Risk-based Testing
Definition: Testing "in which the management, selection, prioritization, and use of testing activities and resources are consciously based on corresponding types and levels of analysed risk" (IEEE, 2022, p. 8)
Parent(s): Requirements-based Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 20), Dynamic Testing? (IEEE, 2022, p. 18)
Notes: Recommended technique for "choosing the subset of possible tests that are most likely to uncover issues of interest" (IEEE, 2022, p. 18); see also the ISO/IEC 25000 SQuaRE family of standards and IEEE, 2022, p. 20

Name: Sandwich Testing
Synonym(s): Mixed Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7)

Name: Scalability Testing
Definition: Testing the "capability of a product to handle growing or shrinking workloads or to adapt its capacity to handle variability" (ISO/IEC, 2023a)
Notes: "Particularly important in distributed or high-performance systems" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Washizaki seems to define it as usability testing (2024, p. 5-9), despite correctly defining "scalability" (2024, p. 5-5). Related to elasticity testing?

Name: Scenario Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising sequences of interactions between the test item and other systems," including users (IEEE, 2022, p. 9), that is "the SUT’s behavioral aspects" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22), Model-based Testing (implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10)
Notes: "Often used with test automation harnesses" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12)

Name: Scripted Testing
Definition: "Testing performed based on a documented test script" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Parent(s): Manual Testing (usually) (IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 33), Automatic Testing ("typically requires more detail") (IEEE, 2022, p. 33)
Notes: "Helps achieve required test coverage levels" (IEEE, 2022, p. 33)

Name: Security Testing
Definition: Testing that validates that "the SUT is protected from external attacks" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) and that "a test item, and associated data and information, are protected so that" only "authorized persons or systems" can use them as intended (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Notes: Verifies "confidentiality, integrity, and availability" and usually includes negative testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9). Good to use when the software will be widely available (IEEE, 2022, p. 45)

Name: Similarity-based Prioritization Testing
Definition: Testing that prioritizes test cases "starting from those most dissimilar according to a predefined distance function" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-8)

Name: Smoke Testing
Definition: Testing that "ensures that the SUT's core functionalities behave properly" and "the SUT is operational before the planned testing begins" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Parent(s): Ad Hoc Testing, Quick Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), Unscripted Testing (implied by Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14), Off-line Testing?
Synonym(s): Build Verification Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)
Notes: "Prevents failures because of the test environment" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-14)

Name: Specification-based Testing
Approach Category: Technique (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; IEEE, 2022, p. 22; Souza et al., 2017, p. 3; implied in IEEE, 2022, pp. 2-4, 6-9)
Definition: "Testing in which the principal test basis is the external inputs and outputs of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9) that "select[s] a few test cases from the input domain that can detect specific categories of faults" (Washizaki, 2024, pp. 5-10--5-11)
Synonym(s): Black-Box Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; IEEE, 2022, p. 9; International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022; IEEE, 2017, p. 2; van Vliet, 2000, p. 399), Domain Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10), Closed-Box Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9), Input Domain-Based Testing (implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8), Functional Testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 399)
Notes: Should be done before structure-based testing to avoid bias towards "test cases based on how the module works" (Patton, 2006, p. 113). Difference between this and functional testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 399; Souza et al., 2017, p. 3)?

Name: State Transition Testing
Definition: Testing "derived to cover the states and transitions" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12) "in a state model" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-12; IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 22), Model-based Testing (Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10)
Notes: Washizaki implies the SUT is represented by a finite-state machine (2024, p. 5-12). See also Patton, 2006, pp. 79-87

Name: Statement Testing
Definition: Testing "based on exercising executable statements in the source code of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Parent(s): Control Flow Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13), Structure-based Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22)

Name: Static Analysis
Definition: "Involves the use of tools to detect anomalies in code or documents without execution" (IEEE, 2022, p. 18)
Notes: See also ISO/IEC 20246

Name: Static Testing
Definition: "Testing in which a test item is examined against a set of quality or other criteria without the test item being executed" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Notes: "Helps form an optimal test strategy" (IEEE, 2022, p. 21), "can be performed anywhere in the life cycle" (IEEE, 2022, p. 17), including "prior to dynamic testing[,] and can find defects before test execution becomes possible" (IEEE, 2022, p. 21). Not always considered "testing" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-2). See also ISO/IEC 20246

Name: Statistical Testing
Notes: "Usage-based statistical testing is applied more during the acceptance testing stage" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15); how to track this? Implied to be related to random testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)

Name: Stress Testing
Definition: Testing of "the SUT beyond its capabilities [done] by generating a load greater than what the system is expected to handle" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9) or providing insufficient resource availability (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Parent(s): Non-functional Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9), Performance Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9), Performance-related Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Boundary Condition Testing (Patton, 2006, p. 86)

Name: Structure-based Testing
Approach Category: Technique (Washizaki, 2024, pp. 5-10, 5-13; implied in IEEE, 2022, pp. 2, 4, 6, 9)
Definition: Testing "derived from an examination of the structure of the test item" (IEEE, 2022, p. 9)
Parent(s): Dynamic Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; IEEE, 2022, pp. 9, 17), Static Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13)
Synonym(s): White-Box Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; IEEE, 2022, p. 9; International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022; Patton, 2006, p. 55), Glass-Box Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; IEEE, 2022, p. 9; International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022; Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, p. 439), Code-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13; implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-8), Structural Testing (IEEE, 2022, p. 9; International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022), Clear-Box Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10; International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022; Patton, 2006, p. 55)
Notes: "Can be performed at different levels (such as code development, code inspection, or unit testing)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-13). International Software Testing Qualifications Board (2022) has more synonyms

Name: Syntax Testing
Definition: Testing based on "the SUT specifications in a formal language" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Parent(s): Specification-based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11; IEEE, 2022, p. 22), Functional Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11), Static Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-10), Model-based Testing (implied by Bourque and Fairley, 2014, p. 4-10)
Synonym(s): Formal Specification-Based Testing (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Notes: "Permits automatic derivation of functional test cases[,] … provides an oracle for checking test results" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11), and "permit[s] desired properties of the specified software to be proved" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-10). Test cases can be generated from these formal requirements (e.g., BDD scenarios and state models), but "determining an expected result is not always possible" and may require "additional business domain expertise" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-20). See also (Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, pp. 448-449; Intana et al., 2020, p. 260)

Name: System Testing
Definition: "Testing the behavior of the SUT", usually in regards to "non-functional system requirements" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-7).
Notes: A system is "an interacting combination of elements to accomplish a defined objective" that includes "hardware, software, firmware, people, information, techniques, facilities, services, and other support elements" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-5; originally from INCOSE). Only the software component is in scope of this research; this is done in some cases where "the software is itself the system of interest, and hardware and support system are regarded as the platform or infrastructure" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 1-5)

Name: Tours
Definition: Testing that is quite general and "guides testers through the paths of an application like a tour guide leads a tourist through the landmarks of a big city" (IEEE, 2022, p. 34)

Name: t-Wise Testing
Definition: Testing that "considers every possible combination of [some] t input" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)
Notes: "More than one pair is derived (i.e., by including higher-level combinations)" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-11)

Name: Unit Testing
Definition: "Testing of individual hardware or software components" (IEEE, 2012, p. 8)
Synonym(s): Component Testing (IEEE, 2022, pp. 12-13; International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022; Peters and Pedrycz, 2000, p. 444), Module Testing (International Software Testing Qualifications Board, 2022; Patton, 2006, p. 109)
Notes: Difference between this and component integration testing? A component is an "entity with discrete structure … within a system considered at a particular level of analysis" (ISO/IEC, 2023) and "the terms module, component, and unit [sic] are often used interchangeably or defined to be subelements of one another in different ways depending upon the context" with no standardized relationship (IEEE, 2017, p. 82). These components "could be the individual subprograms or components, a subsystem, or a composition of … components" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-6). However, "component" is sometimes defined differently than "module": "components differ from classical modules for being re-used in different contexts independently of their development" (Baresi and Pezzè, 2006, p. 107). See also Engström and Petersen, 2015

Name: Unscripted Testing
Definition: "Testing in which the tester's actions are not prescribed by written instructions in a test case" (IEEE, 2022, p. 15)

Name: Usability Testing
Definition: Testing that "evaluate[s] how easy it is for end-users to learn to use the software" by testing functionality, documentation, and/or recovery (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Synonym(s): Human-Computer Interaction Testing? (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-10)
Notes: Related to acceptance testing (van Vliet, 2000, p. 439)

Name: Usage-based Testing
Definition: Testing that "usually rel[ies] on a usage model or profiles" in the context of "the actual operational environment" and "usage by the target stakeholder" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-15)

Name: Volume Testing
Definition: Testing to assess "the SUT’s internal storage limitations and its ability to exchange data and information" (Washizaki, 2024, p. 5-9)

Notes: See also the ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119 series (especially 29119-4); 29119-2 provides more information on test processes
See also ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology -— Vocabulary
Compare ISO/IEC TR 19759:2016 to SWEBOK
Investigate convertibility/functional size measurement (IEEE, 2017, p. 103)
